stories.text:
1. For an understanding to be valid, there must not be - any - arguments that can be made without a reasonable solution.

(E.g. Socrates is a man), no clear conflicting logic can be generated regarding this statement of material fact.

2. If arguments can be presented, but not properly resolved, due to flaws in the logic of an object and/or system, then our understanding of the system - or the system itself is invalid.

(E.g. 2 + 2 = 4 in every circumstance. -> If 2 + 2 = 12 on just only Friday, then our conceptual understanding of math would be invalid, OR math itself would be flawed by not having consistency and predictability)

3. A paradox is equivalent to an argument that cannot be properly resolved and therefore (2) -> our understanding of the system - or the system itself is invalid.

(E.g. Epicurean paradox exists around Theology, which humans agree we have no conclusive understanding of)

-> Paradoxes exist in the most fundamental areas of space and time (E.g. Zeno's Paradox) (2) -> our understanding of the system - or the system itself is invalid.

4. Humans understand space / time, we are able to produce empirical experiments to validate our theories.

(E.g. We are able to observe the expansion of the universe and rotation of the Earth around the Sun)

-> Therefore the system itself must be invalid.

5. Original objects/systems are definitively valid because they are the original, but copies can be invalid.

(E.g. The Mona Lisa cannot be flawed, as any element is by itself the definition of the Mona Lisa), but copies can, which are flaws their reproduction.) (Important Note: The element need not be immediately recognizable, it may require something as minute as Radiocarbon dating to distinguish the variance)

-> Paradoxes expose the flaws within copies of an original object/system, which however minute, expose a flaw and (4) therefore the system itself must be invalid.
